string_table.string: To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.
Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
You must complete the question before submitting.
Enter your name in the field below:
You have reached the time limit set for the quiz. Press 'OK' to continue.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

terms.term: The actual cash value (i.e., fair value) of a used vehicle that is being traded-in on a new vehicle; even if the customer is given a higher trade-in allowance, the vehicle typically is entered in inventory at the ACV.
The fixed operations of the dealership, i.e., the body shop, service department, and parts department.
A finders fee paid to someone who refers a customer to a particular salesperson.
The wholesale value contained in one of the used vehicle valuation guides, such as the Black Book; used as guidance in determining the ACV.
Rate set by the financing institution for loans to customers of the dealership.
Dealers who sell older and less expensive vehicles to customers who may be credit risks. The dealership keeps the notes (carrying the paper) rather than selling the notes to a financing institution.
A manufacturer who has a controlling interest in the respective floor plan lender (i.e., Toyota Motor Credit).

Represents excess funds deposited with the dealerships financing institution for the purpose of reducing monthly interest charges on the floor plan; interest income is generally earned at the dealerships floor plan line of credit interest rate.
See: Cash Management Account

Notes receivable for vehicle sales or leases that have been approved by a financing institution but for which the proceeds have not yet been received; arise when the dealership arranges the financing for the customer.

Certain types of auto parts can be recycled or remanufactured for future sale; these parts have a core price that is used as a form of deposit on the portion of the part that can be remanufactured and that is designed to encourage return of the old part. Parts that may have a core price include brake shoes, brake master cylinders, water pumps, starters, alternators, and air conditioning compressors. See also New Cores, Dirty Cores, Used Cores.
An invoice prepared by the parts department reflecting either a wholesale or retail sale of parts; also called a parts ticket.
A product the dealership can sell to customers whereby upon the customers death the vehicle is paid off.
See: Customer Satisfaction Index
The payment of a portion of the floor plan liability that is owed on certain vehicles that have not sold within a stated time period to ensure that the amount financed does not exceed fair value.
Funds received on future vehicle sales; reclassified at year-end if material for financial statement presentation.
A measurement of polled data obtained by the manufacturer to evaluate the customer service performance of the dealership; also known as Service Satisfaction Index (SSI)
Management report that presents daily and month-to-date sales activity, gross profit, and expense information by department.

term.title: Deal Jacket / Deal File / Deal Folder

terms.term: A file set up for each vehicle sale that contains all the paperwork relating to the sale.
Arrangements between the dealership and a financing institution for a floor plan line of credit.
Monthly, manufacturer-specific statements generated by the dealership and submitted to the manufacturer after month-end close.
A receivable for the amount of finance income earned from selling customer contracts to a financing institution.
A dealership exchanges a new vehicle with another vehicle; transfers can only be made by dealerships of the same franchise.

Software used by virtually all franchise dealerships to operate in all departments, including accounting, financing, and inventory operations; most common include CDK, Reynolds & Reynolds, and DealerTrack.
A vehicle typically driven by sales personnel of the dealership that is always available for demonstration purposes to dealership customers.
The used and returnable parts that are awaiting return to the manufacturer. Also known as Used Cores.
See: Dealership Management Software
See: Daily Operating Control Report
The practice of maintaining more than one new vehicle franchise at one common physical location (i.e., Toyota and Mazda).

term.title: Extended Warranty Contract / Extended Service Contract

terms.term: Contracts that cover the cost of specified mechanical repairs to new vehicles after the expiration of factory warranties and to used vehicles; generally administered by a third-party which relieves the dealership of any continuing liability; dealership records the profit when the contracts are sold and record a payable for the cost of the contract to be remitted to the third-party administrator.
Finance & Insurance Office
Income earned on vehicles being financed and insured through the dealership. See Finance Income.

term.title: Factory Parts Statement / Factory Open Account Statement

terms.term: A monthly or weekly statement from the factory detailing parts purchases and other charges, as well as incentives and credits paid; balance of statement can be a receivable or a payable depending on the timing of the transaction.
Unearned amounts that the dealership pays to the financing institution for defaults on or early payoffs of loans made to customers to finance vehicle purchases.
The commission earned from selling customer contracts to a financing institution; may be determined in a variety of ways, such as stipulated percentage of the principal amount or a flat fee.

Method most service technicians are paid, based on the amount of time that is expected for them to perform a certain job. For example, if a job is estimated to take two hours and it actually takes three to complete, the technician is still paid at the flat rate (two hours). Conversely, if they complete the work in one hour, they are still paid at the full flat rate (two hours).

Rebate received from the manufacturer for the interest expense charged under the floor plan agreement for the time the vehicle was in transit from the factory to the dealership; it may also take other forms, such as interest-free periods or reduced rates for a prescribed time to encourage faster turnover. For GAAP purposes, this allowance is treated as a trade discount, or a reduction of inventory cost if the allowance is received when the vehicle is received from the manufacturer.
An arrangement through which the dealership borrows money from a financing institution to finance its vehicle inventory; vehicles are used as collateral for the loan.

term.title: Floor Plan Line of Credit / Non-Trade

terms.term: Floor plan financing on vehicles with a floor plan lender where a manufacturer does not have a controlling interest (i.e., Bank of America); this type of lender is referred to as a non-captive lender. Cash flows for this type of financing are classified as financing activities

term.title: Floor Plan Line of Credit / Trade

terms.term: Floor plan financing on vehicles purchased from a manufacturer that has a controlling interest in the respective floor plan lender (i.e., Toyota Motor Credit); this type of lender is referred to as a captive lender. Cash flows for this type of financing are classified as operating activities.
The agreement between the manufacturer and the dealer that grants the dealer the right to sell new vehicles of that franchise.
New and used vehicle sales departments; also referred to as variable operations.
Gas, oil, grease
A product the dealership can sell to customers whereby upon the vehicle being totaled, the insurance contract pays the gap between insurance payoff and financial institution payoff.
Adds cost to the vehicle while it is in inventory, with the offsetting credit recorded to a pack reserve contra-inventory account. See also Packs.

A receivable from the manufacturer for an amount (generally 2.5% - 3.5% of the vehicles invoice cost) that is added by the manufacturer to the invoice; often paid to the dealership monthly or quarterly.
The portion of commissions received on canceled insurance policies that must be refunded by the dealership to the insurance company.
A service department work order (i.e., reconditioning a used vehicle or switching radios on a new vehicle) that is also used for interdepartmental billing.
Manufacturers document that assigns ownership of a new vehicle to the dealership; also known as a Manufacturers Statement of Origin (MSO)
Manufacturers document that assigns ownership of a new vehicle to the dealership; also known as a Manufacturers Certificate of Ownership (MCO)
Also known as the sticker price.
See Manufacturer's Certificate of Ownership

The sticker placed on a new vehicle by the manufacturer that presents federally required information such as the MSRP of the vehicle, manufacturer-installed optional equipment, and mileage comparisons.
See: Manufacturers Statement of Origin
See Manufacturer's Suggested Retail Price
National Automobile Dealers Association
Unused parts that have a core price.
Lender providing floor plan financing where the manufacturer does not have a controlling interest (i.e., Bank of America).
The result of a dealership selling a vehicle but not paying off the related floor plan liability within the time specified on the floor plan agreement.

The amount at which the ACV of the customers trade-in is below (under allowance) or above (over allowance) the trade-in allowance given to the customer; difference is recorded as a reduction to sales (over allowance) or an increase to sales (under allowance) at the time the trade-in is received.

A way to allocate some otherwise non-allocable G&A (general and administrative) expenses to the cost of a vehicle. This allows commissionable gross to be more accurately reflected and forces the vehicle sales departments to be aware of these costs to maintain a healthier gross profit when negotiating deals with prospects/customers. See also Hard Packs and Soft Packs.
Amount of service, parts, and accessory items sold to customers on open account (credit).
Computerized perpetual inventory of parts that shows the part number, quantity on hand, and unit cost (at current replacement cost).
An invoice prepared by the parts department reflecting either a wholesale or retail sale of parts; also called a counter ticket.
See Pre-Delivery Inspection

Funds established for the cashiers use in making change for customers and/or small purchases which cannot be paid for conveniently by check; these two types of petty cash funds should be kept separately.

term.title: Policy Work / Policy Adjustments / Policy Expense

terms.term: Providing customer with free parts or services to maintain the customers good will.
Inspection performed on new vehicles prior to final customer delivery; cost for this service is oftentimes reimbursed to the dealership from the factory.

Inventory-related compensation received from the manufacturer; accounted for as a reduction to the total purchase price of the vehicle (if a customer rebate), or a reduction to cost of sale (for a dealer rebate) and recorded as a receivable at the time of deal posting.
Repairing and cleaning a used vehicle to prepare it to be sold.

An invoice for repairs performed by the service department for retail customers, warranty repairs, or internal repairs; also serves as a work order for detail work to be performed by the service department.
A provision for finance income that may be unearned because of defaults on or early payoffs of notes receivable; this is a GAAP adjustment and the deduction cannot be taken for income tax purposes.
See Repair Order
Vehicle provided to a customer as a courtesy while repairs and maintenance are performed on the customers car.
A measurement of polled data obtained by the manufacturer to evaluate the customer service performance of the dealership; also known as Customer Satisfaction Index (SSI)

The service department employee who makes the initial contact with the customer, writes up the repair order, notes if the repair will be covered by a warranty, and determines that the repair is completed to the customers satisfaction.
Used to decrease the commissionable gross on sale of the vehicle. See also Packs.
Extra pay earned by a salesperson for meeting certain sales goals; many times given in cash and later taxed on the employees paycheck.
Releasing a vehicle to the customer before the financing institution has approved the credit application.
See: Service Satisfaction Index

Internal identification number assigned to a vehicle when it arrives at the dealership for use in the dealerships subsidiary ledgers for accounts such as the vehicles inventory, contracts in transit, taxes, titles, licenses, and vehicle receivables.
Repairs performed by a third-party; repairs will be billed to the dealership, who will then bill them to the customer.
Amounts collected from customers for sales taxes, title fees, and license plates that must be remitted by the dealership to taxing authorities.

Group consisting of twenty (at the most) non-competing dealerships of approximately the same size who sell the same type of vehicle but not in the same market. Financial information from the members is distributed monthly for comparison purposes and best practices are shared within the group.
See Tax, Title & License
The used and returnable parts that are awaiting return to the manufacturer. Also known as Dirty Cores.
New and used vehicle sales departments; also referred to as front end.
A unique set of digits that represents the key features of a car or other vehicle (i.e., make, type, seat belts, price class, engine type, year of production, production plant, serial number).
The outstanding loan balance (lien) on a vehicle being traded in that the dealership pays off from the proceeds of the subsequent sale.
Balances due form customers for purchase of vehicles sold on open account which include: Cash down payments Cash purchase of vehicles Fleet purchases Portion of the sale not paid on a contract
See Vehicle Identification Number

Repairs made under a warranty contract that the manufacturer pays the dealership to make; the manufacturer sets the rates that the dealership can charge for such work. When work is completed, a receivable from the manufacturer is established and the dealership submits appropriate paperwork to the manufacturer for reimbursement.

Services or items due to customers after delivery of the vehicle, usually of aftermarket items such as tinting, pin striping, sound systems, etc.; may also be services such as free oil changes or tire rotation.
Term used when a dealership sells a pre-owned vehicle to another dealership or at auction.
Cost of all productive mechanical labor hours and the cost of all parts on repair orders in process.
